title: Ryan sets terms for House speaker role
text:
Paul Ryan agrees to run as House speaker under certain conditions Barney Jopson in Washington ©Getty 
Paul Ryan has given Republicans hope of filling a leadership vacuum in Congress, saying he would be willing to serve as speaker of the House of Representatives if the party unites behind him and accepts certain conditions. 
Mr Ryan , a congressman and the party’s 2012 vice-presidential candidate, on Tuesday evening laid out a series of demands that the fractious Republican party would have to accept for him to take the top job in the House. More Congressional chaos spurs US debt fears 
At a closed-door meeting he asked colleagues to decide whether or not they would support him by Friday, in effect laying down an ultimatum for hardcore conservative lawmakers whose uncompromising criticism of their own leaders has torn the party apart. 
Mr Ryan’s move ensures that confusion over the party’s future will continue for at least a few more days as lawmakers barrel towards a series of critical deadlines, including a possible breach of the federal debt ceiling in early November that only congressional action can avert. 
Congressional Republicans have been in turmoil since John Boehner announced last month he would step down as speaker and his expected successor Kevin McCarthy ended his bid for the job at the last minute amid infighting. 
Mr Ryan, who chairs the House’s tax writing committee, had spent weeks saying he did not want to be speaker. 
He told reporters on Tuesday night he was “reluctant” to take the job but said: “I came to the conclusion that this is a very dire moment, not just for Congress, not just for the Republican party, but for our country. I think our country is in desperate need of leadership.” I think our country is in desperate need of leadership 
A spokesman for Mr Ryan said: “If the members agree with his requests and share his vision, and if he is a unity candidate — with the endorsement of all the conference’s major caucuses — then he will serve as speaker. He will be all in. But if he is not a unifying figure for the conference, then he will not run.” 
Among other conditions, Mr Ryan said the House rules should be changed to make it less easy for rank-and-file members to launch moves to eject their leader. 
“No matter who is speaker, they cannot be successful with this weapon pointed at them all the time,” his spokesman said. 
Mr Ryan, who has three young children, also told members that “family comes first”. 
As the US approaches another debt ceiling, Republicans need a leader 
Read more 
“A successful speaker must be able to maintain a healthy work-family balance. Less time on the road can be compensated for with a greater focus on communicating our message to the public,” his spokesman said. 
Before Tuesday the prospect of a Ryan candidacy had received a mixed reception from the House Freedom Caucus, a small band of conservative lawmakers who consistently undermined Mr Boehner and played a central role in pushing him out. 
Mr Ryan said the next speaker needed “to use the platform to create a clear policy choice for the country”, according to his spokesman. Related Topics Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2015.
